awd_titl_txt: Investigating The Origins Of Social Inequality
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, co-PI's Dr. Brigitte Kovacevich and Dr. Michael Callaghan will carry out a two-year research project including archaeological field and laboratory work focused on the site of Holtun, Guatemala with an international team of scholars.  This research will focus on the development and maintenance of social inequality.  Inequality is a defining characteristic of all prehistoric complex societies and and is of contemporary relevance because it characterizes all societies which exist in the world today.  Archaeologists speculate that it first became formalized within and between households, although little is currently known about how households contributed to emergent ideologies and were innovators and creators of that ideology.

 The objective of this research is to determine how households contributed to social inequality at the Preclassic-period (900 BCE-150 CE) site of Holtun, Guatemala. The investigators central hypothesis is that social inequality developed at Holtun circa 300 BCE, and social complexity circa CE 25, with the support of both emergent elite and commoner households at the site through the medium of communal ritual and the economy associated with it. The central hypothesis will be tested by, 1) identifying and studying the development of social inequality through variation in Middle Preclassic-period (600-300 BCE) household inventories, 2) identifying and studying the differential contribution of households to communal ritual and economic activity through time, and 3) identifying the source and changes in ritual practice and symbols within and between households through time. Principal methods include excavation into domestic and monumental architecture, and analysis of artifacts using both traditional and contemporary approaches including: ceramic and lithic typological classification, petrography, lithic microwear analysis and replication studies, faunal analysis, X-ray Fluorescence, stable-isotope analysis of human bone, Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis, and soil geo-chemistry studies. 

This project will promote teaching, training, and learning by employing graduate, undergraduate, and Dallas-area high school students to engage in archaeological research, training, and experimental studies. The research includes underrepresented groups, specifically women in science. While the number of women attaining doctoral degrees in the social sciences has risen, women in archaeology still have not achieved equal employment and representation in the field. The research also incorporates Latino high school students from one of Dallas Counties poorest cities and provides training for an international team including Guatemalan undergraduates. The results of this research will be broadly disseminated to the international community at conferences and meetings. Results will be published in annual archaeological site reports and available online at a project website through SMU's server with data available to the public on tDAR and/or the Open Science Framework.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to determine how households of all social levels contributed to the development of social inequality at the Preclassic-period (600 BCE-150 CE) site of Holtun, Guatemala and what role household activities played in the development of social complexity. Our central hypothesis was that social inequality developed at Holtun with the support of both emergent elite and commoner households through the medium of communal ritual and the economy associated with it. This hypothesis was supported by findings that suggest most, if not all households were involved in communal feasting and ritual production during the Middle Preclassic period (600-300 BCE) with participation and production becoming restricted to certain households and monumental areas by the Late Preclassic period (300 BCE-150 CE).  During the Late Preclassic period leadership strategies then shifted from a focus on communal participation in ritual and feasting to warfare and violence. This shift may have resulted in a collapse and depopulation of the site following the Late Preclassic period. The intellectual merit of this research is that it allowed us to see how the actions of household members actively contributed to and simultaneously contested the development of social inequality and complexity in the Maya lowlands, which has broader implications for the role that everyday households play in the promotion and support of emergent leaders.

 The analyses that allowed us to test our hypotheses included new methodologies for soil sampling of large plaza areas that were successful and can be used at other sites.  Soil testing can detect changes in activity patterns through time when no artifact remains are present and give clues to ritual and economic behavior.  A new technology was also applied to low relief artistic renderings (often called graffiti), including Reflectance Transformation Imaging (RTI), which allowed us to record and analyze images of warfare and sacrifice at the end of the Preclassic period that signaled ideological shifts. This technology can be used in similar contexts in other sites and around the world to more fully understand fragile, low relief, art and artifacts. Other studies included the first isotopic analysis of human bone from the Maya Preclassic period showing differences in status related food consumption through time. Faunal analysis of animal remains demonstrated feasting behavior that was widespread throughout the site (especially in terms of freshwater shellfish consumption) with certain exotic and difficult to attain species becoming more restricted through time.  Handheld X-Ray Fluorescence technology (XRF) was used to characterize obsidian (volcanic glass used for utilitarian and ritual cutting tools) from the site to examine trade and exchange relationships through time. Using Geographic Information Systems (GIS) to plot changes in obsidian sources in time and space helped us to find that certain sources (especially El Chayal) were restricted to elites in earlier periods and then became more widespread through in later periods, these trade relationships may have been a source of power for emergent elites.  XRF technology was also applied experimentally to ceramic slips, demonstrating different colored slips were compositional distinct, but still correlated with some typological classifications.  Instrumental Neutron Activation Analysis (INAA) of ceramics also showed a particular type of ceramic (Mars Orange) was the first trade ware in the Maya lowlands, and another source of economic and social power for emergent elites. 

 The broader impacts of the project included teaching, training, and learning by providing the research for 5 American and 1 Guatemalan graduate students earn MA’s and PhD’s, 1 American undergraduate student to earn a BA, and 5 undergraduate Guatemalan students to earn Licenciaturas. This research included underrepresented groups, specifically training women in science and Hispanic students. In order to enhance infrastructure for research and education multiple large and small equipment were purchased and are now being shared by American and Guatemalan faculty and students including microscopes, handheld GPS devices, Total Stations, XRF and cameras. The results of this research have been broadly disseminated to the international archaeological community and the public through conference papers, posters, technical reports, and peer-reviewed publications (most available online through Open Science Framework, researchgate, academia.edu, and Facebook). Collections are located in lab facilities in Mixco, Guatemala.  Research was included in 10 sections of 5 classes at UCF (ANT2000, ANT4171, ANT3160, ANT4932, ANG5228) taught by Kovacevich and Callaghan since 2015 and reached an audience of 1162 students (undergraduates and graduates). The research has been presented to the public in the U.S. including talks at the Orlando Museum of Art, Institute for Maya Studies, Maya at the Playa, Archaeological Institute of America-Jacksonville, Central Florida Anthropological Society, College of Science Distinguished Lecture Series at University of Central Florida, and in Guatemala at the Museo Popol Vuh.  Results will continue to be disseminated in conferences, peer-reviewed publications, and public lectures.
